title: 15 Things Girls Who Suck At Makeup Understand

comments.text:
If people don't support Photoshop editing your face to conceal your 
wrinkles, pimples or bags under your eyes etc... Then why support the 
constant use of make-up? People bitch about how people use software to hide 
stuff on their face, but then spend money and time on hiding stuff on their 
face..? I don't get it.﻿

comments.author: Aathmika Krishna

comments.text:
I don't know why girls are so obsessed with wearing makeup. The only makeup 
I've ever worn in my entire life was eyeliner. And I've even stopped 
wearing it because it takes away from my natural beauty. So now I don't 
wear makeup at all, ever. No one complains that I look tired or unkept. In 
fact, I'm always getting compliments from people saying that I have such 
beautiful skin. I've also never had that all-out acne that most teens get. 
Makeup damages your skin, too.

It seems like every girl I know wears makeup. One time on a school band 
trip, everyone was given time to change into business casual clothing for 
an important convention. Because we had all just come from a long, 
overnight bus ride, LITERALLY every girl in the restroom we were using (I 
looked around the entire restroom) was putting on makeup except for me and 
my sister. I've never understood why girls feel such an intense need to 
wear makeup.﻿
comments.author: Leah リーア トニー

comments.text: So me!^^﻿

comments.text: Sneezing while Trying to Put Mascara on is the Worst. 😒﻿

comments.text:
+Derek G  Haha yeah I was exagerating quite a bit to make a point, but you 
get the gist of it :P As you said, people do what they do with their 
appearance because they enjoy it (And if per chance they didn't, no one 
would really know that person's reasons unless 1. you were that person 2. 
you were reallyyyy close to that person)
comments.author: sillyspacecadet396

comments.text:
+sillyspacecadet396 
To be ready for a zombie apocalypse you need a plan and tools, not an 
outfit. So I mean, yeah, we have associations with certain outfits and 
colors, but I think in the end, we need to realize they aren't what make us 
who we are -- it's not like if we take a "daring" piece of clothing off our 
brain suddenly becomes incapable of being daring. I'm not going to think 
someone is better than me just because of what clothing they wear. That 
doesn't mean don't enjoy it, clothing and such is probably satisfying for 
most; we just need to remember it doesn't give you magical powers :) 
Destroying civilizations singlehandedly would fit that category, and I 
don't know, while I'm sure you said that in jest, it nevertheless sounds 
like there is a lot of ego behind one's eyebrows if they're saying things 
like that.
comments.author: Derek G

comments.text: +sillyspacecadet396 Haha, well said- good point.
comments.author: Loki Wolfe

comments.text:
+Loki Wolfe You'd be pretty surprised to find out that pleasing men is not 
the main reason why women wear makeup...Many people (because I'm pretty 
sure there are people other than women who wear makeup) wear it as a means 
of expression, or to bring out a feature they like on their face, or even 
just because it's fun (let's face it, makeup is basically a grownup version 
of face painting). It's kind of like clothes: I assume you buy or wear 
clothes you like/think look good on you-That button-up is hot on you, and 
that suit makes it look like you got your whole life together, and OH YEAH 
these pants make you feel like you're ready for the zombie apocalypse. Same 
concept with makeup: some will wear a red-hot lipstick because they think 
they look hella rad with it, while others will get their eyebrows done 
because hey, when your eyebrows are on fleek, you could destroy 
civilizations if you really wanted to.
comments.author: sillyspacecadet396

comments.text:
+eartianwerewolf I understand your point, but some women (who believe they 
*really* need makeup due to the 'poor' or 'unfair' cards they were dealt, 
genetically) will pile it on thick trying to get themselves a man, and they 
will oft continue to do so every time they see them after establishing a 
relationship with that man to keep up appearances. What is that man going 
to think, years down the road, when he finally sees his [now] lover without 
any paint on her face? People are generally superficial and tend to want 
the most beautiful person that they are able to get their hands on (no pun 
intended). I'm just saying, for a man who can really see past the physical 
'flaws' of a woman, that should be the type of man that a woman would want 
to spend the rest of her life with- not the man who is just looking for the 
hottest woman he can find, and later become disappointed at how the woman 
actually looks when they are not all dolled up.
comments.author: Loki Wolfe

comments.text:
I do think makeup does improve appearance. It depends on how important that

comments.author: Rushana Ahmed

comments.text:
I still like to wear makeup when I want but it's no longer because I feel 
'yuck' without it or because 'I have an interview so I have to look the 
part' that's when I feel make up has gone wrong, when confidence and lack 
of confidence depends on how much make up we have on, that's sad. Or worse, 
doing it for attention from men or to prove 'we're pretty'. We should be 
able to be happy without it and just wear it when and if we want without 
feeling terrible or judged by others.﻿
comments.author: Sama “sunrise” r

comments.text:
From someone who used to love wearing make up to someone whos stopped (for 
religious and otherwise personal reasons). I can totally agree that people 
treat you differently, I'll get girls look me up and down because I 
look'plain' to them, some are literally open mouthed when I show up to a 
wedding fresh faced which is just ridicolous. I'll get comments like'oh you 
look tired today' at work when I've slept fine , it's just I haven't 
drowned my eyes in concealer and foundation to look 'fresh'. The funny 
thing is guys couldn't really care less, they treat me the same, fine I 
don't get flirted with (Im married anyway and my husband hates make up) but 
thats more my clothing choices now I feel than make-up. I think it's wrong 
that women feel they 'have to wear it', not wearing it has made me feel 
confident in my own skin and stand up to the negative pressure. Funny how 
that works out. ﻿
comments.author: Sama “sunrise” r

comments.text:
To do your eyeliner here's a tip. Do a regular line of eyeliner, but use 
tape as guideline for winged eyeliner. I do this everyday before I go to 
school and always get compliments on it because your winged eyeliner 
actually turns out pretty even w/ sharp lines﻿
comments.author: Zuri Nelson

comments.text: this is so me!! feel better without it..﻿
comments.author: Dian Mayasari

comments.text:
Here's something for people learning to do makeup: it's hard at first but 
just keep practicing and take your time. Don't rush into anything and don't 
go for the more expensive products right away because practicing a lot will 
cause you to go through it fast. Wait, until you think you've got it, to 
buy the expensive brands. 
Here's something for people that are friends with or are around beginners: 
do not, I repeat DO NOT make the person feel bad if they don't have it 
perfected right away. If they are out and about with you and you see some 
looks a little bit messed up or odd, don't make fun of them; help them out. 
If you are good with makeup give them tips. If you discourage them it's not 
gonna make them better, just make them feel like they want to give up. ﻿
comments.author: gigi brooks

comments.text: This whole video is me. idk but thank you for this ㅋㅋ﻿
